item.title: Germany’s Got a Problem, and It’s More Than Donald Trump
item.description: As Donald Trump pushes ahead with his campaign to transform the way the world does business, Germany is uniquely vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Marilen Martin

media:content.media:description: A viewing point looking out over the Schwelgern coking plant at ThyssenKrupp’s Duisburg steelworks in April.

item.title: Elon Musk Urges Americans Take Action to ‘Kill’ Trump Tax Cut Bill
item.description: Elon Musk is on a mission to block President Donald Trump’s tax bill after he tried — and failed — to convince Republican lawmakers to preserve valuable tax credits for electric vehicles in the legislation, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Vietnam Says It Is Responding to US Demands With ‘Goodwill’
item.description: Vietnam said it is responding to US demands with “goodwill” as it seeks to address the Trump administration’s concerns over the Southeast Asian country’s trade gap with the US and avoid crippling duties.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

item.title: Xi Tells Lukashenko China Will Hold Military Parade on Sept. 3
item.description: President Xi Jinping said China will hold a military parade to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II on Sept. 3, an event that’s expected to bring his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Jing Li, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kevin Frayer/Getty Images Photographer: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Trump Orders Inquiry Into Biden’s Health, Use of Autopen
item.description: President Donald Trump directed aides to investigate whether former President Joe Biden’s staff conspired to hide information about his health from the public and enacted any executive actions without his predecessor’s knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Joe Biden Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP

item.title: Trump Stymied in ‘Art of the Deal’ Approach to World’s Strongmen
item.description: President Donald Trump has long boasted about his ability to cut deals with the world’s strongmen. But now that he’s back in the White House, his charms haven’t worked on the leaders he professes to admire.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Bars Foreign Students From Entering US to Attend Harvard
item.description: President Donald Trump signed an executive action that prevents foreign nationals from entering the US to study at Harvard University, accusing the school of failing to implement discipline on campus and fostering a dramatic rise in crime.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Trump has sought to reshape Harvard’s policies on a wide-range of issues, including admissions and faculty hiring practices.

item.title: China Offers $1,400 Bounty for Arrests of Taiwan Cyberwarriors
item.description: China placed a bounty on cyberwarriors working for Taiwan’s Defense Ministry, extending its campaign to squeeze President Lai Ching-te.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann

media:content.media:description: Computer code and text displayed on computer screens. Photographer: Bloomberg Creative Photos/Bloomberg Creative Collection

item.title: Kim Vows Full Backing for Putin as Ties With Russia Deepen
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un reiterated his pledge to unconditionally support Russian President Vladimir Putin, state media said, as the sanctions-defying alliance between the two countries raises security concerns in the region.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by the North Korean government, Kim Jong Un, second right, meets with Sergei Shoigu, left, in Pyongyang, North Korea, on June 4. Source: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service/AP Photo

item.title: US to Keep Pressure on Vietnam Over China Imports, Lutnick Says
item.description: The Trump administration will keep up pressure on Vietnam as long as it keeps re-exporting a significant amount of Chinese products to the US, according to Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes operate at the Tan Vu Terminal, operated by Vietnam Maritime Corp., at Haiphong Port in Haiphong, Vietnam, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. Vietnam Maritime, the state-owned shipping, logistics and seaports company previously known as Vietnam National Shipping Lines or Vinalines, plans to expand its fleet by 20% annually in the next five years,

item.title: The Rare-Earth Fight Imperiling US-China Trade Peace, Explained
item.description: Markets cheered in early May when the US and China agreed in Geneva to lower tariffs and other barriers. But after a few weeks, the shine started to come off that deal, with China accusing the US of violating it with new restrictions and the US saying China failed to honor promises on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Neodymium is displayed at the Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Rare-Earth Hi-Tech Co. factory in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Wednesday, May 5, 2010. A generation after Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping made mastering neodymium and 16 other elements known as rare-earths a priority, China has cornered the market, with far-reaching effects ranging from job losses and global trade to U.S. national security.

item.title: Hong Kong Bolsters Top Court With First Foreign Judge in a Year
item.description: Hong Kong has appointed a retired New Zealand judge to its top court, the first foreign justice named to the appellate body in over a year following record resignations that threatened to undermine confidence in the judicial system.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: The Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong.

item.title: Senate GOP Plans to Boost CFPB Scrutiny, Cut Fed Employee Pay
item.description: The Senate Banking Committee is planning to eliminate all mandatory funding for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and restrict the pay of many Federal Reserve employees as part of the Senate’s big tax and spending bill, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Christopher Condon

media:content.media:description: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. In another weekend takeover of a federal agency's operations, staffers from an efficiency initiative led by billionaire Elon Musk helped to effectively shut down the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, as they gained access to an array of the bureau's protected information.

item.title: Trump Signs Travel Ban for 12 Countries Including Afghanistan
item.description: President Donald Trump signed a proclamation that bans individuals from 12 countries from entering the US, reinstating one of the most controversial measures from his first term after an attack in Colorado that targeted an event supporting Israeli hostages.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference with Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Trump Violated Rights of Deported Venezuelans, Judge Rules
item.description: A US judge ruled that the Trump administration violated the due-process rights of more than 100 Venezuelans deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador, and they must now get a chance to challenge their removal.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A penitentiary security officer at the Terrorism Containment Center (CECOT) maximum security prison in Tecoluca, El Salvador, on Thursday, Sept. 7, 2023. El Salvador's prison population has tripled to 100,000 in less than two years under President Nayib Bukele's crackdown on gangs, his security minister said, disclosing for the first time how many people the government has jailed.

item.title: Trump Broadcasts Putin Vow to Respond to Ukraine Attacks
item.description: Donald Trump on Wednesday broadcast Vladimir Putin’s warning that he’ll retaliate against Ukraine for its recent stunning drone strikes deep inside Russian territory, the clearest signal yet that the US president’s peace efforts have stalled.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump

item.title: Trump, GOP Senators Discussed Cutting SALT Break in Tax Bill
item.description: Donald Trump and Republican senators discussed ways to scale back the $40,000 state and local tax deduction cap in the House version of the president’s tax-cut bill, Senate Majority Leader John Thune said.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune

item.title: Trump’s Late-Night Lament Over Xi Deepens Impasse in Trade Fight
item.description: President Donald Trump is positioning a personal discussion with his Chinese counterpart as the key to preventing the world’s largest economies from spiraling deeper into their trade and technology fight.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump, left, and Xi Jinping.

item.title: Trump Officials Target Columbia Accreditation Over Pro-Palestine Protests
item.description: The Education Department said Columbia University no longer appeared to meet accreditation standards after concluding that the school is in violation of anti-discrimination laws, the latest effort by the Trump administration to target elite schools over their handling of pro-Palestinian protests.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Student demonstrators occupy the pro-Palestinian "Gaza Solidarity Encampment" on the West Lawn of Columbia University on April 24, 2024 in New York City.

item.title: Lutnick Says Hurricane Center’s Fully Staffed Despite Key Vacancies
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told a congressional committee that the US National Hurricane Center was fully staffed even though key positions are going unfilled as hurricane season begins.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan, Alicia Diaz, Lauren Rosenthal

media:content.media:description: Hurricane models on monitors at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Hurricane Center in Miami.

item.title: Why the Trade War Is Keeping US Inflation Down—For Now
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we discuss consumer pessimism and how legal challenges to Donald Trump’s tariffs might play out.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: MIAMI, FLORIDA - JANUARY 12: Edwin Lopez sorts the money in the cash register at Frankie's Pizza on January 12, 2022 in Miami, Florida. The eatery's co-owner, Renee Pasquarella, said the cost for everything needed to run the business — from cardboard boxes to pizza ingredients including cheese, tomatoes, meat — has gone up. She said that in the 67 years the pizza place has been serving customers this has been one of the toughest times to keep it open. The Labor Department released a report indicating that the consumer price index rose 7 percent in December, compared to a year ago, the fastest increase since June 1982. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)

item.title: The CBO Has Good News and Bad News on Trump Tax Bill
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the Congressional Budget Office forecasts for the Republican tax and spending cut bill. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joe Sobczyk

item.title: Trump Budget Plan Raises Concern Over Cuts to Statistics Bureau
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing to cut resources from the Bureau of Labor Statistics when the agency is already reeling from years of budget constraints, further compounding concerns about the quality and quantity of data produced about the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Attendees wait in line to enter a career fair in Sacramento, California.

item.title: Three of US’s Top Steel Suppliers Are Seeking Breaks on Tariffs
item.description: The US’s top steel providers are racing to win exemptions from Donald Trump’s steel tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Simone Iglesias, Mariana Durao

media:content.media:description: A worker cuts steel sheets at an auto parts manufacturer in San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi state, Mexico, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. US President Donald Trump's potential tariffs against Canada and Mexico will threaten production at automakers across North America and send record vehicle prices even higher.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Government Shaky as Political Allies Eye Exit
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government faces the possibility of collapse and early elections after his ultra-Orthodox coalition partners on Wednesday threatened to bolt, according to Israeli media.
item.dc:creator: Marissa Newman

media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2025.

item.title: Walmart Fires Workers, Reviews Permits Over Immigration Ruling
item.description: Walmart Inc. is informing stores across the country to begin identifying workers whose work authorization may be expiring after the Supreme Court ruled that the Trump administration could revoke protections for hundreds of thousands of migrants.
item.dc:creator: Daniela Sirtori, Jaewon Kang

media:content.media:description: A Walmart store in Cromwell, Connecticut, US, on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023. Walmart Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on November 16. Photographer: Joe Buglewicz/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Gets a Tentative Win From CBO's New Tax and Tariff Estimates
item.description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office handed Republicans a major political talking point Wednesday, with projections that showed the possibility for President Donald Trump’s tariffs to bring in more federal revenue than will be lost by his giant tax-cut plan.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Carney Holds Back on Tariff Retaliation, Says US-Canada Talks Are Progressing
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada and the US are in “intensive” talks about the countries’ trade relationship, explaining his government’s decision not to respond yet to the Trump administration’s doubling of steel and aluminum tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister.

item.title: USDA to Review Reports Following Delay of Latest Trade Outlook
item.description: The US Department of Agriculture is undergoing a review of non-statutory reports including a quarterly forecast on trade that pointed to a record farming deficit.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares soybeans for planting at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies.

item.title: Modi Not Invited to G-7 Summit in Sign of Frayed Canada Ties
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is not expected to attend the Canada-hosted Group of Seven summit, a first in six years and a sign of frosty ties between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister.
